:::blockquote{.notes-only}
In the beginning was the Tao. The Tao gave birth to Space and Time.
Therefore Space and Time are the Yin and Yang of programming.
:cite[— [Tao of Programming](https://www.mit.edu/~xela/tao.html)]
:::

##  Binary Numbers 

In decimal system, a number is expressed as a sequence of digits $0$ to $9$.
For example, `Two thousand twenty one ⇔ 2021`

In binary number system the set of digits, is called binary digits or :sc[bits]: $\{0, 1\}$.  

A binary number is expressed as a sequence of bits.  
For example, $183$ in binary is $10110111$.

## Converting from decimal to binary

::decimal-binary

## Converting from binary to decimal

::binary-decimal

## Groups of bits

A group of $8$ bits is called a :i[byte]  e.g. $11010111$
- $1$ kilobyte (kB) = $1000$ bytes
- $1$ megabyte (MB) = $10^6$  (million) bytes
- $1$ gigabyte (GB) = $10^9$ (billion) bytes
- $1$ terabyte (TB) = $10^{12}$ bytes (1000 billion)

## What is programming?

Programming is the process of creating a set of instructions — a program — to tell a computer how to perform a task.

Programs take input data, perform some computation — numerical or symbolic (text) — and produce output data.

Computers can perform only basic binary operations (such as add or multiply two numbers)
- How do we communicate complex instructions to computers? — Use a programming language!


## Levels of programming languages

:::div{.my2}
| Low-level languages                                    | High-level languages                              |
|--------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------|
| Closer to machine, difficult for humans                | Closer to humans,  easier for humans to work with |
|                                                        |                                                   |
| Less portable, provide  less abstraction over hardware | More portable, more abstraction over hardware     |
| Examples: Assembly Language                            | Examples: Java, Python                            |
:::


## How do computers understand high-level languages? :style{.ppt-tight}

High-level languages are translated into Machine code (for CPU). 

Programming languages come in two main flavors — :i[compiled] languages or :i[interpreted] languages:  

:::div{style="font-size: 0.9em; margin: 0 -3em 0 -3em;"}
| :sc[Compiled] (e.g. C/C++, Java)                                       | :sc[Interpreted] (e.g. Python)                                            |
|:------------------------------------------------------------------------|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| High-level program (source code)  ➞  :sc[compiler] ➞ binary executable | High-level program (source code) ➞ Executed directly by :sc[interpreter]  |
|                                                                        |                                                                           |
| Once compiled, the binary program can be executed without compiler.    | The interpreter is required on the machine where the program is executed. |
:::

::divider

## Data in binary

Computers can understand only binary numbers  

How can we encode data in the real world into binary numbers?

::img{src="module-1/data-in-binary.svg" style="margin: 2rem auto;" .ppt-w110}

## Integers in binary

We already saw how to represent positive integers in binary e.g.  
:div[$109 = 1101101_2$]{style="text-align: center;"}
For signed integers (to differentiate negative and positive), an extra leftmost bit is used for sign only, e.g.  
    :div[$-109 = \colorbox{lightblue}{1}1101101_2$]{style="text-align: center;"} 
    :div[$+109 = \colorbox{lightblue}{0}1101101_2$]{style="text-align: center;"}

::div[(For more info: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signed_number_representations)]{.smaller}

## Real numbers in binary

64-bit :sc[Floating point] format is used to represent numbers with decimal point, e.g.  
:div[$\colorbox{lightblue}{0}\colorbox{lightpink}{10000000000}\colorbox{lightgreen}{1001001000011111101101010100010001000010110100011000} = 3.141592653589793$]{style="text-align: center;"}

Floating point format has a :i[finite precision], but digits of $\pi$ run forever: :div[$3.1415926535897932384626433832795028841...$]{style="text-align: center;"}

But with only 64-bits we can only have precision up to a fixed digits after decimal point: $3.141592653589793$

::div[(For more info: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double-precision_floating-point_format)]{.smaller}

## Text in binary

::p[Letters and punctuations in human languages are encoded in binary using a :i[Character Encoding] such as ASCII or UTF-8 (Unicode).]{.ppt-m-3}

::image{style="margin: 0 auto; width: 80%;" src="module-1/ASCII-Table.png" .ppt-img50}  
::div[(source: https://simple.wikipedia.org/wiki/ASCII)]{style="font-size: 0.6em; margin: 0 auto;"}

## Images, audio & video in binary

Even for these complex data, the idea remains the same.  

We use a format to store bytes in a file and programs know what to do (play music, show image, etc) based on the format.  

We already know some of these formats:
- Images: jpeg, png
- Audio: mp3, m4a, wma
- Video: mp4, avi, wmv


::divider

## Thonny Demo — Editor vs Shell

Python interpreter can work in an interactive or :i[shell] mode in which lines of code are executed immediately as soon as they are entered and output is visible immediately.  

Shell mode is apparent whenever you see the prompt `>>>`.

In :i[Script] mode, a Python file (`.py`) is executed by interpreter as a program (whole file, not line-by-line).

Thonny allows us to use both modes.

## Comments

Comments are annotations we add to our program and are ignored by the Python interpreter.

In Python, we start a comment using `#`.

```python
# Author: Deven
# My first program

# This is a comment on its own line & it will be ignored
print("Hello, world!")  # str
print(123)  # int
print(1.614)  # float 
```

##    
We use comments to:
- Make the code easier to read and understand by explaining how it works.
- Indicate authorship and license.
- Disable some code (prevent it from executing) but still keeping it in the file.


In Thonny, we can use `Edit menu -> Toggle comment` to comment/uncomment the selected lines.


## Objects and Data Types

All data in a Python program is represented by :sc[objects]. An object always has a :sc[type] (or :sc[class]) associated with it.

:::div{.hgrid}
```python
>>> 5
5
>>> 3.1415
3.1415
>>> "Hello"
'Hello'
```
```python
# Using type() function to know the type of objects
>>> type(5)
<class 'int'>
>>> type(3.1415)
<class 'float'>
>>> type("Hello")
<class 'str'>
```
:::

##

An object's type determines the operations that the object supports:

```python
#  objects of int type can be added using +
>>> 10 + 5
15

# But an object of type str cannot be added to an int using +
>>> "Hello" + 5
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<pyshell>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: can only concatenate str (not "int") to str
```

## Summary
 
We saw the three basic data types in Python:
- `int`: Integers such as $..., -1, 0, 1, 2, ...$
- `float`: Floating-point numbers such as $-1.2, 3.14,$ etc.
- `str`: Text data (a sequence of characters) such as "hello world", "Python", etc.

The terms :sc[Object] and :sc[Value] are used interchangeably.  
So are the terms :sc[Class] and :sc[Type].


::divider

## Review of last week All data in a Python program is represented by :sc[objects]. An object always has a :sc[type] (or :sc[class]) associated with it. - `int`: Integers such as $..., -1, 0, 1, 2, ...$ - `float`: Floating-point numbers such as $-1.2, 3.14,$ etc. - `str`: Text data (a sequence of characters) such as "hello world", "Python", etc. In Thonny, we can use `Edit menu -> Toggle comment` to comment/uncomment the selected lines. ## Variables In Python, a :sc[Variable] is a name that refers to an object in computer memory. A variable can be created using :sc[Assignment Statement]: :::div{.center .code .my3} :span[variable_name = value]{.bgblue .p1 .br5} ::: `=` is known as the :sc[assignment operator]. ## ```python # create a variable and assign it value 20 temperature = 20 # variable temperature refers to 20 which is displayed print("Today's temperature is", temperature) # show type of the variable print("Type of temperature variable is", type(temperature)) ``` ```output Today's temperature is 20 Type of temperature variable is ``` ## Arithmetic with numbers Calculations with numbers can be done using :i[arithmetic operators]. ::::div{.hgrid} :::div ```python # Addition print(1.5 + 1.5) # 3.0 # Subtraction print(10 - 20) # -10 ``` ::: :::div ```python # Multiplication print(42 * 42) # 1764 # Division print(1 / 5) # 0.2 # Exponentiation (x to the power of y) print(2 ** 16) # 65536 ``` ::: :::: ## ```python temperature = 20 # Unary minus operator print(-temperature) # -20 # Computing rest mass energy of an electron rest_mass = 9.109e-31 # Using scientific notation speed_of_light = 3e8 rest_mass_energy = rest_mass * (speed_of_light ** 2) # E = mc^2 print(rest_mass_energy) # 8.198099999999999e-14 ``` ## Floor division and remainder ::img{src="module-2/divmod.svg" style="margin:2em;"} ```python # floor division print(20 // 3) # 6 # remainder print(20 % 3) # 2 ``` ## ```python # Converting seconds to minutes duration = 320 print(duration, "seconds equal", duration / 60, "minutes.") # 320 seconds equal 5.333333333333333 minutes. # Alternative approach: minutes = duration // 60 seconds = duration % 60 print(duration, "seconds equal", minutes, "minutes and", seconds, "seconds.") # 320 seconds equal 5 minutes and 20 seconds. ``` ## Result type of arithmetic operations For all operators (except division `/`): - if one or more of the operands are of type `float`, result value will have type `float` - if both operands are of type `int`, result value will have type `int`. For division operator `/`: - the result value is always of type `float` regardless of whether the operands are of type `int` or `float`. ## ```python x = 2 + 1 print(x, type(x)) # 3 x = 2 + 1.0 print(x, type(x)) # 3.0 # Classic division always results in float x = 1 / 2 print(x, type(x)) # 0.5 ``` :::div{.px2 .py1 .my2 style="border: solid 1px lightgray; border-radius:5px; background-color: #d6efd6;"} :b[Try the above examples with other operators!]{.p0} ::: ## Basic string operations Strings are sequences of zero or more characters. In Python, strings are enclosed by either single or double quotes. ```python "Hello" 'everyone!' "I'm Batman." # single quote allowed inside double quotes, 'You can call me "Bruce".' # and vice versa. '123' # this is a string, not a number! "" # this is an empty string " " # this is a string with just one space ``` ## ```python # a multi-line string using triple quotes """The woods are lovely, dark and deep, But I have promises to keep, And miles to go before I sleep, And miles to go before I sleep. """ # We can also use single quotes for multi-line strings '''I hold it true, whate'er befall; I feel it when I sorrow most; 'Tis better to have loved and lost Than never to have loved at all. ''' ``` ## String concatenation (joining) using `+` operator ```python message = "Hello" + "everyone" print(message) # Helloeveryone name = "Alice" message = "Hello " + name print(message) # Hello Alice string = "1" + "2" + "3" print(string) # 123 and not the number 6 price = 100 print(price + " USD") # TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'int' and 'str' ``` ## String repetition String can be repeated multiple times using `*` operator. ```python print("Welcome! " * 3) # 'Welcome! Welcome! Welcome! ' print(4 * "ha") # 'hahahaha' ``` ## String length The function `len()` returns length of its argument string. ```python password = "xyz1234" print("Password length:", len(password)) # Password length: 7 print(len(1234)) # TypeError: object of type 'int' has no len() ``` ## More on Variables Let us write code that implements the following formula to convert fahrenheit to celsius: $$c = \frac{5(f-32)}{9}$$ ```python print("10 F in C is", 5 * (10 - 32) / 9) ``` ## :span[Variables allow "saving" intermediate results of a computation]{style="font-size: 0.83em;"} We can use variable to store the result so that we can reuse it in the program later. ```python fahrenheit = 10 # Store the result of the expression celsius = 5 * (fahrenheit - 32) / 9 print(fahrenheit, "F in C is", celsius) # Use variable celsius for more calculations print("Adding 10 degrees today:", celsius + 10) ``` ## :span[Variables can be reassigned new values]{style="font-size: 0.85em;"} ```python # Create variable name "number" and assign a value to it number = 123 print(number) # displays 123 # Assign new value to existing variable "number" number = -50 print(number) # displays -50 # add 10 and assign the result value to existing variable "number" number = number + 10 print(number) # displays -40 ``` ## New values can be of different type.
## However, variables should be changed with caution as it can produce errors or strange results. ```python number = 123 # an int value message = "hello" # a string # Now variable number refers to the string "hello" number = message print(number * 2) # String repetition! print(number - 10) # minus won't work with string. ``` ```output hellohello Traceback (most recent call last): print(number - 10) TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for -: 'str' and 'int' ``` ## Example: Swapping values Sometimes we need to swap (interchange) values of two variables. ::::div{.hgrid style="width: 110%;"} :::div A naive attempt (does not work): ```python x = 137 y = 42 # Try swapping x = y y = x print(x, y) # 42 42 ``` ::: :::div The following will work: ```python x = 137 y = 42 # Correct way to swap temp = x x = y y = temp print(x, y) # 42 137 ``` ::: :::: ## Rules for variable names - A variable name can only contain alpha-numeric characters and underscores `A-Z, a-z, 0-9, _` - A variable name cannot start with a number - Variable names are case-sensitive - (`cat`, `Cat`, and `CAT` are three different variables) - They cannot be keywords. - Python has 33 reserved keywords, you can see a list of them by typing `help("keywords")` in the Python shell. :::div{.px2 .my2 style="border: solid 1px lightgray; border-radius:5px; background-color: #d6dcef;"} Python filenames must follow the same rules as above. ::: ## Good practice for naming variables :::div{.ppt-m-3 .ppt-mt-1} - Name your variable something descriptive of its purpose or content. - If the variable is one word, all letters should be lowercase. Eg: `hour`, `day`. - If the variable contains more than one word, then they should all be lowercase and each separated by an underscore. This is called :i[snake case]. e.g. `is_sunny`, `cat_name` - Good variable names: `hour`, `is_open`, `number_of_books`, `course_code` - Bad variable names: `asfdstow`, `nounderscoreever`, `ur_stupid`, `CaPiTAlsANyWHErE` ::: ## Function calls Function take zero or more input values, perform an action or computation, and return the result value. Input values passed to a function are called :sc[arguments]. A :sc[Function Call] is an expression that looks like below: :::div{.center .code .my3} :span[function_name(argument1, argument2, ..., argumentN)]{.bgblue .p1 .br5} ::: How do we say it? — function "takes" argument(s) and "returns" a result. The result is also called the :sc[return value]. ## The number of arguments required by a function depends on how that function is defined. Following are some built-in functions available in Python: ```python # min() function takes 2 or more numbers and returns the minimum x = min(1, -4, 6) print(x) # -4 # abs() function takes a number and returns absolute value of the number y = abs(-6) print(y) # 6 # Gives an error if we do not give exactly one number z = abs(-1, 4) # TypeError: abs() takes exactly one argument (2 given) ``` ## Expressions vs Statements An :sc[Expression] is any valid combination of values, variables, operators, function calls. When executed, it always evaluates to a single object. ```python x = 3 y = 4 z = x ** 2 + y ** 2 # this expression evaluates to an int object print(z) # 25 s = "hello" s2 = s * len(s) # this expression evaluates to str value print(s2) # hellohellohellohellohello ``` ## A statement is one or more lines of code that performs an action but does not evaluate to any value. So, statements cannot be used as a part of an expression. ```python >>> x = 123 # Does not evaluate to anything so nothing shows below >>> x # This is an trivially an expression 123 >>> 10 + (x = 123) # Trying to use assignment statement in an expression 10 + (x = 123) ^ SyntaxError: invalid syntax ``` ## Order of Expression Evaluation When we have different operators the same expression, which operator should apply first?. All Python operators have a :sc[precedence] and :sc[associativity]: - Precedence — for two different kinds of operators, which should be applied first? - Associativity — for two operators with the same precedence, which should be applied first? ## Table below show operators from higher precedence to lower. :::div{.my2 .hgrid} | Operator | Associativity | |---------------------|---------------| | `()` (parentheses) | - | | `**` | Right | | Unary `-` | - | | `*`, `/`, `//`, `%` | Left | | Binary `+`, `-` | Left | | `=` (assignment) | Right | ::: ## ```python x = 3 y = 5 # Multiplication has higher precedence than addition z = x + 2 * y + 1 print(z) # 14 # Need to use parentheses to enforce the order we want z = (x + 2) * (y + 1) print(z) # 30 # Same precedence so left to right z = x * y / 100 print(z) # 0.15 ``` ## ```python # Same as 2 ** (3 ** 2) because "**" goes right to left z = 2 ** 3 ** 2 print(z) # 512 # Using parentheses to enforce the order we want z = (2 ** 3) ** 2 print(z) # 64 x = 5 x = x + 1 # addition happens first and then assignment print(x) # 6 ``` ::divider

## Function composition
Function composition is calling one function with the result of another function.

It is a very useful thing to do especially when we do not need to store intermediate results.

::::div{.hgrid}
:::div
::div[Using intermediate variables]{.b}
```python
x = -5
y = -8
abs_x = abs(x)
abs_y = abs(y)
z = min(abs_x, abs_y)
print(x, y, z)
```
:::

:::div
::div[Using composition]{.b}
```python
x = -5
y = -8
z = min(abs(x), abs(y))
print(x, y, z)
```
:::
::::

## Types of Errors

:b[Syntax Errors]: When syntax is incorrect such as wrong punctuations, invalid characters, missing quotes or parentheses etc.  
Program does not run at all in the case of syntax errors.
```python
# The following code has Syntax error due to missing double-quotes:
x = 5
print("Square of x is)
print(x ** 2)
```

##

:::div{.ppt-f94}
:b[Runtime Errors], also called :sc[Exceptions], occur when there is a problem in the program during execution.  
All code executes until an exception occurs.
```python
# The following code produces NameError because 
# variable y was not created before it is used.
x = 5
print("Value of x is", x)
print("Square of x is", y ** 2)
```

:b[Semantic] or Logic errors are said to occur when a program executes without a problem but does not produce correct output as expected.

:sc[Debugging] is the process of finding and removing errors in a program.
:::

## :span[Debugging in Thonny for better understanding order of evaluation]{.ppt-f80}

:::div{.ppt-f87}
In Thonny, we can use debugging features to understand how expressions are evaluated:

- To show variables and their values, go to menu "View -> Variables"
- First, run program in :i[debug mode] by clicking the "Debug current script" button (located next to the "Run current script" button and looks like a bug)
- Then, we have two options:
    - Run the program line-by-line using "Step over" button next to the "Debug" button
    - Run program going inside each expression using "Step into" button (located next to "Step over" button)
:::

## 

Try the following examples in Thonny and use debug:

::::div{.hgrid .ppt-f80}
:::div
```python
x = 7

# Increment value of variable x by 1
x = x + 1

#
y = x * x + 2 * (x + 1) + max(x + 1, 5)

# Calling print() with 4 arguments
print("x =", x, "y =", y)
```
:::
:::div
```python
message = "Hello"

# Calling print() with 1 argument
print("+" + "-" * (len(message) + 6) + "+")

# Calling print() with 3 arguments
print("+", "-" * (len(message) + 6), "+")
```
:::
::::

## Defining a function

A function is a :i[named] block of code that performs a task.

So far we have been using (calling) functions to do specific tasks — `print()`, `input()`, etc.

We can also define/create our own function:

```python
def function_name(arg1, arg2, ..., argN):  # function header
    # function body
    statement1
    statement2
    .
    .
    statementN
```

##

- `def` is a Python keyword used to define functions
- Notice how statements are indented by spaces, typically 4 spaces. In Thonny, we can just use tab key once to indent by 4 spaces.

- When we define a function using `def` keyword:
    - it is not executed.  
    - Only the function name is created, which refers to the code block inside the function.
- When we call a function, the code block inside the function is :i[actually] executed.


## Function with no arguments

:span[Such functions always do the same thing each time they are executed.]{.ppt-f94}

::::div{.hgrid}
:::div
```python
# Function definition
def display_greeting():
    print("+------------+")
    print("|  Welcome!  |")
    print("+------------+")

# Function call
display_greeting()

# Call it again
display_greeting()
```
:::

:::div
```output
+------------+
|  Welcome!  |
+------------+
+------------+
|  Welcome!  |
+------------+
```
:::
::::


## :span[Functions with arguments and return value]{.ppt-f90}
A function can return a value using `return` statement.

::::div{.hgrid}
:::div
```python
def f(x):
    result = x * x - x - 1
    return result
    # OR: return x * x - x - 1

# Call the function f
y = f(5)
print(y)  # 19

# Call again
y = f(10)
print(y)  # 89
```
:::
:::div
```python
# two arguments
def mean(x, y):
    return (x + y) / 2


print(mean(3, 4))  # 3.5
```
:::
::::

##

:::div{.bgred .px2 .py025 .br5}
Parentheses `()` are required to call a function. Omitting them is a common mistake.

When a function is called, correct number of arguments must be passed. It is an error to pass too many or too few arguments than what a function definition expects.
:::

## Why create our own functions?

- Functions allow code re-use; duplication of code can be avoided.
- They help organize code into sections, which makes programs easier to read and understand.
- They make programs easier to fix.


## Docstrings

A :sc[docstring] (documentation string) is a multiline (triple-quoted) string that we write after the header of a function to explain how the function works.

It is an important part of programming to write such documentation.  
You will be expected do so in your assignments.

##

```python
def euclidean_distance(x1, y1, x2, y2):
    """
    Computes Euclidean distance between two 2D points.

    Args:
        x1: x-coordinate of first point (float) 
        y1: y-coordinate of first point (float) 
        x2: x-coordinate of second point (float) 
        y2: y-coordinate of second point (float) 

    Returns: the euclidean distance as a float
    """
    d = (x1 - x2) ** 2 + (y1 - y2) ** 2
    return d ** 0.5
```

::divider
